text: But we also find archaea throughout mesophilic soil and water, and within the digestive tracts of humans and other animals.
Other archaea cooperate with eukaryotes, for example, by colonizing the surface of plant roots.
Perhaps the most compelling unique feature of archaea, from the human point of view, is that no archaea are known to cause disease.
While surveying their major taxonomic categories, we introduce research techniques used to study organisms in extreme environments and those with unique forms of metabolism, such as methanogenesis.
Extremophiles are of interest to biotechnology because their enzymes may catalyze reactions under industrially useful conditions, such as high salt or acidity.
Even in these shared habitats, archaea show unique traits, such as energy-yielding methanogenesis and cyclic diether membranes.
Each grappling hook contains paired barbs along an extended protein filament many times the length of the cell.
In 1977, Carl Woese revealed the existence of a third kind of life—the Archaea, a domain of life-forms very different from the plants, animals, and bacteria that had long been known.
Moissl-Eichinger even discovered archaea on human skin, comprising more than 4% of the skin’s prokaryotic microbiome.

Recent reports find gut methanogens associated with the inflammatory response, but no causal relationship has yet been demonstrated.
